results.title: Omni
results.brief_description:
Finbar is a young man who is obsessed with pi. His fragile existence is thrown into tumult when he discovers a mysterious note in his locker…

Under the category ‘Secondary Live Action’, Blake Whelan, ACT, was the Screen It 2012 winner.

results.title: Sunday's dog
results.creator_credit: Fionnuala Keith, Maddie Jamieson Goddard and Pepper Horman
results.brief_description:
When Sunday went to live with her grandmother she didn’t have any friends to play with. One day a stray dog walked down the lane behind her house. It was missing a tail and an ear. Nobody wanted it. Sunday made friends with the dog but it was taken away to the pound. Weeks passed. Dogs were adopted and other dogs were led away to a big blue door. Finally, Sunday found the dog at the pound and adopted him. When they got home, Sunday made him a special hat with two ears and a tail for him to wag. Creators: Pepper Horman, Maddie Jamieson Goddard, Fionnuala Keith, Jennifer Petroploulos, Lucy Hanna, Declan Warren, Piper McLeod, Amy Phillips, Elan Cotter, Georgia Dickie, Isabella Godfrey, Lucinda McSherry, Millie Barnes, Nick Warren, Ella O’Donoghue, Isobel Hyett, Michael Guzzardi, Lucy Phillips, Clare Olding and Jagger Skilbeck.

Under the category ‘Primary Animation’, Years 5 and 6, Yarraville West Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Cubbies
results.creator_credit: Darcy Drake, Kane Jutson, Max Duke and Ryan Dunt
results.brief_description:
Trust, creativity, friendship and belonging are the focus of the ‘Cubbies’ story. A group of friends use cooperation, creativity and sheer ingenuity to build 29 different ‘cubbies’. The trust given by the staff and wider school community is central.

Under the categories ‘Primary Live Action’ and ‘Best Overall Primary’, Years 5 and 6 from Doreen Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Moon to Dust
results.creator_credit: Kanlaya Padungsin and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description: Winner of ‘Best Character Animation’ for RMIT’s AIM Graduate Screenings, 2009. Set to the song of the same name by Georgia Fields, ‘Moon to Dust’ is a beautiful and melancholic rendering of belonging, isolation and change.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kanlaya Padungsin and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT

results.title: Fire and water
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions
results.brief_description:
Roxby Downs, in South Australia and run by Western Mining (later BHP Billiton), is the world’s largest uranium mine. It also sits on sacred Aboriginal land and proposals to increase production were considered to have possibly severe implications. The population and culture of the Arabunna and Koktha people could be effected, as could environmental and ecological concerns such as local water levels and quality.

In September 1997, the music festival ‘Roxstop’ was held to prevent these developments to the mine. In amongst the protests and celebrations, activists went on a company-hosted tour of the mine to learn how Western Mining justify their position on expanding operations.

results.title: Atomic footprints
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr and Pip Starr Productions
results.brief_description:
The debate surrounding the production of nuclear energy goes back to the bombing of Hiroshima at the end of World War II. Since then, the proliferation of nuclear energy and weapons has been used as a deterrant, a bolstering of military power and, in the early 2000’s, as a solution to combat global warming.

With the Prime Minister John Howard’s comments regarding not ruling out atomic power stations, this documentary considers the implications to the environment, the people living on the land, our health and our future.

results.title: The Okapa Connection
results.brief_description: In the Purosa region of Papua New Guinea, the community have worked together to produce some of the world’s most sought-after coffee beans. The quality of the beans are such that they are imported to places like Melbourne and have the added benefit of being fair-trade, organic coffee. The growers explain how this industry has been a boon to the community and improved their wealth, while coffee-lovers in Melbourne enjoy good coffee with a clear conscience.

results.title: Through the wire
results.brief_description: In 2002, in amongst raging protests and police reinforcements, more than 40 refugees, rendered desperate by manditory detention, escaped from Woomera Detention Centre in South Australia. Narrated by escaped refugee DJ Moopsie, with powerful music by Mark Daniel, ‘Through the wire’ captures the heightened emotions, despair and desperation of the day and takes us inside the minds of those imprisoned trying to seek a better life.

results.title: Big, grey and tubey
results.creator_credit: Sage Armstrong, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
When the tornado hit, Sage Armstrong and her mother took shelter in the toilet. Traumatised by the experience, Armstrong was able to find solace in helping others in the aftermath.
On the 3rd of June 2010, the residents of Lennox Head, on the North Coast of New South Wales, were preparing for the day ahead when their town was struck by a tornado.

results.title: What else matters?
results.creator_credit: Maree Somerville, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Maree Somerville acknowledges that, despite the devastation, the day could’ve had a different ending - one more tragic. For Somerville, it has been an opportunity to recognise what really matters in life.
On the 3rd of June 2010, the residents of Lennox Head, on the North Coast of New South Wales, were preparing for the day ahead when their town was struck by a tornado.
